Education.</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2d95ddec5f5b3a2bf1b299cd697187bd7/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-15T15:07:52+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.educause.edu/ero/article/penetrating-fog-analytics-learning-and-education"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 15 15:07:52 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>EDUCAUSE review</swrc:journal><swrc:number>5</swrc:number><swrc:pages>30</swrc:pages><swrc:publisher><swrc:Organization swrc:name="ERIC"/></swrc:publisher><swrc:title>Penetrating the Fog: Analytics in Learning and Education.</swrc:title><swrc:volume>46</swrc:volume><swrc:year>2011</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics learning review </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Attempts to imagine the future of education often emphasize new technologies\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdubiquitous computing devices, flexible classroom designs, and innovative visual displays. But the most dramatic factor shaping the future of higher education is something that we can\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt actually touch or see: big data and analytics. Basing decisions on data and evidence seems stunningly obvious, and indeed, research indicates that data-driven decision-making improves organizational output and productivity.1 For many leaders in higher education, however, experience and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgut instinct\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd have a stronger pull.  Meanwhile, the move toward using data and evidence to make decisions is transforming other fields. Notable is the shift from clinical practice to evidence-based medicine in health care. The former relies on individual physicians basing their treatment decisions on their personal experience with earlier patient cases.2 The latter is about carefully designed data collection that builds up evidence on which clinical decisions are based. Medicine is looking even further toward computational modeling by using analytics to answer the simple question \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdwho will get sick?\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and then acting on those predictions to assist individuals in making lifestyle or health changes.3Insurance companies also are turning to predictive modeling to determine high-risk customers. Effective data analysis can produce insight into how lifestyle choices and personal health habits affect long-term risks.4 Business and governments too are jumping on the analytics and data-driven decision-making trends, in the form of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbusiness intelligence.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd  Higher education, a field that gathers an astonishing array of data about its \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcustomers,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd has traditionally been inefficient in its data use, often operating with substantial delays in analyzing readily evident data and feedback. Evaluating student dropouts on an annual basis leaves gaping holes of delayed action and opportunities for intervention. Organizational processes\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsuch as planning and resource allocation\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdoften fail to utilize large amounts of data on effective learning practices, student profiles, and needed interventions.  Something must change. For decades, calls have been made for reform in the efficiency and quality of higher education. Now, with the Internet, mobile technologies, and open education, these calls are gaining a new level of urgency. Compounding this technological and social change, prominent investors and businesspeople are questioning the time and monetary value of higher education.5 Unfortunately, the crescendo of calls for higher education reform lacks a foundation for making decisions on what to do or how to guide change. It is here\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdas a framework for making learning-based reform decisions\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthat analytics will have the largest impact on higher education.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="George Siemens"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Phil analytics to predict (and improve) student success: a faculty benefits learning review </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Dietz-Uhler">Beth Dietz-Uhler</a>,  and <a href="/author/Hurn">Janet E Hurn</a>. rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.ncolr.org/jiol/issues/pdf/12.1.2.pdf"/><swrc:date>Sat Feb 14 17:50:44 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>Journal of Interactive Online Learning</swrc:journal><swrc:number>1</swrc:number><swrc:pages>17-26</swrc:pages><swrc:title>Using learning analytics to predict (and improve) student success: a faculty perspective</swrc:title><swrc:volume>12</swrc:volume><swrc:year>2013</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics benefits learning review </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Learning analytics is receiving increased attention, in part because it offers to assist educational institutions in increasing student retention, improving student success, and easing the burden of accountability. Although these large-scale issues are worthy of consideration, faculty might also be interested in how they can use learning analytics in their own courses to help their students succeed. In this paper, we define learning analytics, how it has been used in educational institutions, what learning analytics tools are available, and how faculty can make use of data in their courses to monitor and predict student performance. Finally, we discuss several issues and concerns with the use of learning analytics in higher education.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Beth Dietz-Uhler"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Janet E Hurn"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/208dd076c954989ddfaac3e52cbb7fe4d/yish"><title>Using data mining for predicting relationships between online question theme and final grade</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/208dd076c954989ddfaac3e52cbb7fe4d/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-14T17:44:07+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics data educational learning mining </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Abdous">M&#039;hammed Abdous</a>, <a href="/author/He">Wu He</a>,  and <a href="/author/Yen">Cherng-Jyh Yen</a>. </span><em>Educational Technology &amp; Society</em> <em>15(3):77-88</em> (<em>2012</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/data"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/educational"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/mining"/></rdf:Bag></taxo:topics><burst:publication><rdf:Description rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/208dd076c954989ddfaac3e52cbb7fe4d/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/208dd076c954989ddfaac3e52cbb7fe4d/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://ifets.info/journals/15_3/6.pdf"/><swrc:date>Sat Feb 14 17:44:07 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>Educational Technology & Society</swrc:journal><swrc:number>3</swrc:number><swrc:pages>77-88</swrc:pages><swrc:title>Using data mining for predicting relationships between online question theme and final grade</swrc:title><swrc:volume>15</swrc:volume><swrc:year>2012</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics data educational learning mining </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>As higher education diversifies its delivery modes, our ability to use the predictive and analytical power of educational data mining (EDM) to understand students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd learning experiences is a critical step forward. The adoption of EDM by higher education as an analytical and decision making tool is offering new opportunities to exploit the untapped data generated by various student information systems (SIS) and learning management systems (LMS). This paper describes a hybrid approach which uses EDM and regression analysis to analyse live video streaming (LVS) students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd online learning behaviours and their performance in their courses. Students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd participation and login frequency, as well as the number of chat messages and questions that they submit to their instructors, were analysed, along with students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd final grades. Results of the study show a considerable variability in students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd questions and chat messages. Unlike previous studies, this study suggests no correlation between students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd number of questions / chat messages / login times and students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd success. However, our case study reveals that combining EDM with traditional statistical analysis provides a strong and coherent analytical framework capable of enabling a deeper and richer understanding of students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd learning behaviours and experiences. </swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="M'hammed Abdous"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Wu He"/></rdf:_2><rdf:_3><swrc:Person swrc:name="Cherng-Jyh Yen"/></rdf:_3></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2c9fa6a270ad10d3d0ddaed1896444728/yish"><title>Translating learning into numbers: A generic framework for learning analytics</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2c9fa6a270ad10d3d0ddaed1896444728/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-14T17:39:07+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics dimensions learning </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Greller">Wolfgang Greller</a>,  and <a href="/author/Drachsler">Hendrik Drachsler</a>. </span><em>Educational Technology &amp; Society</em> <em>15(3):42-57</em> (<em>2012</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/dimensions"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/></rdf:Bag></taxo:topics><burst:publication><rdf:Description rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2c9fa6a270ad10d3d0ddaed1896444728/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/2c9fa6a270ad10d3d0ddaed1896444728/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://ifets.info/journals/15_3/4.pdf"/><swrc:date>Sat Feb 14 17:39:07 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>Educational Technology & Society</swrc:journal><swrc:number>3</swrc:number><swrc:pages>42-57</swrc:pages><swrc:title>Translating learning into numbers: A generic framework for learning analytics</swrc:title><swrc:volume>15</swrc:volume><swrc:year>2012</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics dimensions learning </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>With the increase in available educational data, it is expected that Learning Analytics will become a powerful means to inform and support learners, teachers and their institutions in better understanding and predicting personal learning needs and performance. However, the processes and requirements behind the beneficial application of Learning and Knowledge Analytics as well as the consequences for learning and teaching are still far from being understood. In this paper, we explore the key dimensions of Learning Analytics (LA), the critical problem zones, and some potential dangers to the beneficial exploitation of educational data. We propose and discuss a generic design framework that can act as a useful guide for setting up Learning Analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance, in quality assurance, curriculum development, and in improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency. Furthermore, the presented article intends to inform about soft barriers and limitations of Learning Analytics. We identify the required skills and competences that make meaningful use of Learning Analytics data possible to overcome gaps in interpretation literacy among educational stakeholders. We also discuss privacy and ethical issues and suggest ways in which these issues can be addressed through policy guidelines and best practice examples. </swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Wolfgang Greller"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Hendrik Drachsler"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2f8969363a959179ef81b8564103943e3/yish"><title>Social Learning Analytics.</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2f8969363a959179ef81b8564103943e3/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-14T16:25:08+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics learning social </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Shum">Simon Buckingham Shum</a>,  and <a href="/author/Ferguson">Rebecca Ferguson</a>. </span><em>Educational Technology &amp; Society</em> <em>15(3):3-26</em> (<em>2012</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/social"/></rdf:Bag></taxo:topics><burst:publication><rdf:Description rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2f8969363a959179ef81b8564103943e3/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/2f8969363a959179ef81b8564103943e3/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.ifets.info/journals/15_3/2.pdf"/><swrc:date>Sat Feb 14 16:25:08 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>Educational Technology & Society</swrc:journal><swrc:number>3</swrc:number><swrc:pages>3-26</swrc:pages><swrc:title>Social Learning Analytics.</swrc:title><swrc:volume>15</swrc:volume><swrc:year>2012</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics learning social </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>We propose that the design and implementation of effective Social Learning Analytics presents significant challenges and opportunities for both research and enterprise, in three important respects. The first is the challenge of implementing analytics that have pedagogical and ethical integrity, in a context where power and control over data is now of primary importance. The second challenge is that the educational landscape is extraordinarily turbulent at present, in no small part due to technological drivers. Online social learning is emerging as a significant phenomenon for a variety of reasons, which we review, in order to motivate the concept of social learning, and ways of conceiving social learning environments as distinct from other social platforms. This sets the context for the third challenge, namely, to understand different types of Social Learning Analytic, each of which has specific technical and pedagogical challenges. We propose an initial taxonomy of five types. We conclude by considering potential futures for Social Learning Analytics, if the drivers and trends reviewed continue, and the prospect of solutions to some of the concerns that institution-centric learning analytics may provoke.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Simon Buckingham Shum"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Rebecca Ferguson"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2c4a9dda43ff0c6b209f7490ca211012d/yish"><title>Recommender recommender-systems systems </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Technology enhanced learning (TEL) aims to design, develop and test sociotechnical  innovations that will support and enhance learning practices of both individuals  and organizations. It is therefore an application domain that generally  covers technologies that support all forms of teaching and learning activities.  Since information retrieval (in terms of searching for relevant learning resources  to support teachers or learners) is a pivotal activity in TEL, the deployment of recommender systems has attracted increased interest. This chapter attempts to provide  an introduction to recommender systems for TEL settings, as well as to highlight  their particularities compared to recommender systems for other application  domains.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Nikos Manouselis"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Hendrik Drachsler"/></rdf:_2><rdf:_3><swrc:Person challenges</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2da35bf5e19ac06c57a59c13b50cabaf4/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-14T14:19:54+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://oro.open.ac.uk/36374/"/><swrc:date>Sat Feb 14 14:19:54 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>International Journal of Technology Enhanced Learning</swrc:journal><swrc:number>5</swrc:number><swrc:pages>304-317</swrc:pages><swrc:publisher><swrc:Organization swrc:name="Inderscience"/></swrc:publisher><swrc:title>Learning analytics: drivers, developments and challenges</swrc:title><swrc:volume>4</swrc:volume><swrc:year>2012</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics learning </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Learning analytics is a significant area of technology-enhanced learning that has emerged during the last decade. This review of the field begins with an examination of the technological, educational and political factors that have driven the development of analytics in educational settings. It goes on to chart the emergence of learning analytics, including their origins in the 20th century, the development of data-driven analytics, the rise of learning-focused perspectives and the influence of national economic concerns. It next focuses on the relationships between learning analytics, educational data mining and academic analytics. Finally, it examines developing areas of learning analytics research, and identifies a series of future challenges.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Rebecca Ferguson"/></rdf:_1></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/249504aca0b2272b731f140bc6e555d9f/yish"><title>Scripting and monitoring meet each other: Aligning learning analytics and learning design to support teachers in orchestrating CSCL situations</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/249504aca0b2272b731f140bc6e555d9f/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-08T13:49:24+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning scripting teacher </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Rodr%C3%ADguez-Triana">Mar\ufffd\ufffda Jes\ufffd\ufffds Rodr\ufffd\ufffdguez-Triana</a>, <a href="/author/Mart%C3%ADnez-Mon%C3%A9s">Alejandra Mart\ufffd\ufffdnez-Mon\ufffd\ufffds</a>, <a href="/author/Asensio-P%C3%A9rez">Juan I. Asensio-P\ufffd\ufffdrez</a>,  and <a href="/author/Dimitriadis">Yannis Dimitriadis</a>. </span><em>British Journal of Educational Technology</em>  (<em>2014</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/bjet-si-2015"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/design"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/inquiry"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/scripting"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/teacher"/></rdf:Bag></taxo:topics><burst:publication><rdf:Description rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/249504aca0b2272b731f140bc6e555d9f/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/249504aca0b2272b731f140bc6e555d9f/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/bjet.12198"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 08 13:49:24 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>British Journal of Educational Technology</swrc:journal><swrc:title>Scripting and monitoring meet each other: Aligning learning analytics and learning design to support teachers in orchestrating CSCL situations</swrc:title><swrc:year>2014</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning scripting teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>From the conceptualization to the evaluation of computer-supported collaborative learning (CSCL) scenarios, teachers address multiple tasks, sometimes being overwhelmed on account of the required time and associated burden. To support teachers in this endeavor, we propose to connect the pedagogical decisions made at design time with the analysis of the participants' interactions. Thus, teachers would be provided with relevant and coarse-grained information that could help them manage their CSCL scenarios. This paper synthesizes the main contributions obtained from a 3-year design-based research process, and presents the findings obtained from the evaluation of the current proposal in two authentic CSCL scenarios. The participant teachers valued the proposal positively and stated that it was helpful for their orchestration of CSCL scenarios.</swrc:abstract><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="1467-8535" swrc:key="issn"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="10.1111/bjet.12198" swrc:key="doi"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Mar\ufffd\ufffda Jes\ufffd\ufffds Rodr\ufffd\ufffdguez-Triana"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Alejandra Mart\ufffd\ufffdnez-Mon\ufffd\ufffds"/></rdf:_2><rdf:_3><swrc:Person swrc:name="Juan I. Asensio-P\ufffd\ufffdrez"/></rdf:_3><rdf:_4><swrc:Person swrc:name="Yannis Dimitriadis"/></rdf:_4></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item inquiry</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2573aa665880f2515d38bf04aeecbe8ca/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-08T13:34:42+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2573aa665880f2515d38bf04aeecbe8ca/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/2573aa665880f2515d38bf04aeecbe8ca/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/bjet.12207"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 08 13:34:42 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>British Journal of Educational Technology</swrc:journal><swrc:title>Informing learning design with learning analytics to improve teacher inquiry</swrc:title><swrc:year>2014</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>This paper proposes an analysis of current research in learning design (LD), a field aiming to improve the quality of educational interventions by supporting their design and fostering the sharing and reuse of innovative practices among educators. This research area, at the moment, focuses on three main strands: the representations that can be used as a common language to communicate about pedagogical plans and other half-fabricates of the design process, the methodological approaches to LD and the tools that support the LD process. For each of the three strands, the current landscape is discussed, pointing at open issues and indicating future research perspectives, with particular attention to the contribution that learning analytics can make to transform LD from a craft, based on experience, intuition and tacit knowledge, into a mature research area, grounded on data concerning the learning process and hence supporting enquiry while teachers design, run and evaluate the learning process.</swrc:abstract><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="1467-8535" swrc:key="issn"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="10.1111/bjet.12207" swrc:key="doi"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Donatella Persico"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Francesca Pozzi"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item design</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/20423ef5efe8f6f6e9f9fc260b59622a6/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-08T13:29:57+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/design"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/inquiry"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/><rdf:li rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/20423ef5efe8f6f6e9f9fc260b59622a6/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/20423ef5efe8f6f6e9f9fc260b59622a6/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 08 13:29:57 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:title>Supporting teachers in data-informed educational design</swrc:title><swrc:year>2015</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Recent years have seen a growing recognition of the value of positioning teaching as a design science. In this context, we see a great potential in the possible synergy between educational design, learning analytics, and teacher inquiry. This synergy is demonstrated in the form of CASCADE-SEA, a computer-based support tool that assists teachers in creating exemplary lesson materials for secondary level science and mathematics in southern Africa. The purpose of the present study is to articulate how teachers might be supported in the synergistic processes that are integral to educational design. It does so by revisiting existing data collected during the design, development and evaluation of CASCADE-SEA, and sharing the results of a retrospective analysis in light of recent developments in learning analytics, learning design and teacher inquiry. The retrospective analysis revealed insights related to each of the aforementioned themes. For learning analytics, those were: social structures of learning and teaching practices; pedagogy-driven collection and analysis of data; and the use of data to inform teaching and learning. For learning design, the findings pertained to the language, practices and tools used to achieve particular educational aims. For teacher inquiry, the findings relate to the empirical process of question formulation, methods selection, collection and analysis of data, and sharing/reflecting on the findings as well as overall process. Based on the retrospective analysis, design considerations are offered for a modern application to replace the practical and effective desktop software that was developed during the 1990s.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Susan McKenney"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Yishay Mor"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/29d0e367a6f52d23b55abacf678b02510/yish"><title>Analysing Content and Patterns of Interaction for Improving the Learning Design of Networked Learning Environments</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/29d0e367a6f52d23b55abacf678b02510/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-08T13:27:32+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Haya">Pablo Haya</a>, <a href="/author/Daems">Oliver Daems</a>, <a href="/author/Malzahn">Nils Malzahn</a>, <a href="/author/Castellanos">Jorge Castellanos</a>,  and <a href="/author/Hoppe">Heinz Hoppe</a>. </span><em>British Journal of Educational Technology</em>  (<em>2015</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/bjet-si-2015"/><rdf:li rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/29d0e367a6f52d23b55abacf678b02510/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/29d0e367a6f52d23b55abacf678b02510/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 08 13:27:32 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>British Journal of Educational Technology</swrc:journal><swrc:title>Analysing Content and Patterns of Interaction for Improving the Learning Design of Networked Learning Environments</swrc:title><swrc:year>2015</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Learning Analytics constitutes a key tool for supporting Learning Design and teacherled inquiry into student learning (TISL). In this article we demonstrate how a Social Learning Analytics (SLA) toolkit can combine Social Network Analysis (SNA) and content analysis for supporting a global and formal teacher inquiry. This toolkit does not only support teachers in improving the organization of the learning process but also generates important input to improve the students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd reflection on their own learning. Our examples show how combinations of different levels of analysis can provide deep insight in the learning process. We report a case study that exemplifies the main features of our approach and the kind of outcomes that can be obtained. Commenting and rating processes on videos are analysed based on user traces from a social learning platform. Finally, we point out implications on the Learning Design for networked learning environments in general.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Pablo Haya"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Oliver Daems"/></rdf:_2><rdf:_3><swrc:Person swrc:name="Nils Malzahn"/></rdf:_3><rdf:_4><swrc:Person swrc:name="Jorge Castellanos"/></rdf:_4><rdf:_5><swrc:Person swrc:name="Heinz Hoppe"/></rdf:_5></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/25b353a176d01bda625a78e7ee9aaab7c/yish"><title>Forward-oriented designing for learning as a means to achieve educational quality</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/25b353a176d01bda625a78e7ee9aaab7c/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-08T13:23:17+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Ghislandi">Patrizia Ghislandi</a>,  and <a href="/author/Raffaghelli">Juliana Raffaghelli</a>. </span><em>British Journal of Educational Technology</em>  (<em>2015</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/bjet-si-2015"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/design"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/inquiry"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/teacher"/></rdf:Bag></taxo:topics><burst:publication><rdf:Description rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/25b353a176d01bda625a78e7ee9aaab7c/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/25b353a176d01bda625a78e7ee9aaab7c/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 08 13:23:17 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>British Journal of Educational Technology</swrc:journal><swrc:title>Forward-oriented designing for learning as a means to achieve educational quality</swrc:title><swrc:year>2015</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>In this paper, we reflect on how Design for Learning can create the basis for a culture of educational quality. We explore the process of Design for Learning within a blended, undergraduate university course through a teacher-led inquiry approach, aiming at showing the connections between the process of Design for Learning and academic staff/student reflections on educational quality. As emerges from the evidence collected, forward-oriented design \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd which is Design for Learning as iterative and participatory practice (Dimitriadis & Goodyear, 2013) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd supports meta-learning on the practices and values of educational quality. We introduce in depth the two main constructs adopted in our work \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Design for Learning and educational quality \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in order to understand the ongoing debate in these two separate (but convergent) areas of research. The four phases (design for configuration, design for orchestration, design for reflection, design for re-design) show the impact of design on educational quality reflections and practices. Alongside the process of Design for Learning, the data is collected and analyzed adopting different methods that enable the researchers to better understand the diverse perspectives of staff and students. We conclude that Design for Learning can be deemed a mediational instrument to explore methods of transforming existing educational situations into desired situations, linking the vision of educational quality with concrete practices of the teacher and students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd daily activities.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Patrizia Ghislandi"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Juliana Raffaghelli"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2db12b5aebcadcb1203b89ac1f3ba185c/yish"><title>How was the activity? A visualization support for a case of location-based learning design</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2db12b5aebcadcb1203b89ac1f3ba185c/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2015-02-08T13:15:50+01:00</dc:date><dc:subject>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Melero">Javier Melero</a>, <a href="/author/Hern%C3%A1ndez-Leo">Davinia Hern\ufffd\ufffdndez-Leo</a>, <a href="/author/Sun">Jing Sun</a>, <a href="/author/Santos">Patricia Santos</a>,  and <a href="/author/Blat">Josep Blat</a>. </span><em>British Journal of Educational Technology</em>  (<em>2015</em>)</content:encoded><taxo:topics><rdf:Bag><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/analytics"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/bjet-si-2015"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/design"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/inquiry"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/learning"/><rdf:li rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/tag/teacher"/></rdf:Bag></taxo:topics><burst:publication><rdf:Description rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2db12b5aebcadcb1203b89ac1f3ba185c/yish"><owl:sameAs rdf:resource="http://www.bibsonomy.org/uri/bibtex/2db12b5aebcadcb1203b89ac1f3ba185c/yish"/><rdf:type rdf:resource="http://swrc.ontoware.org/ontology#Article"/><swrc:date>Sun Feb 08 13:15:50 CET 2015</swrc:date><swrc:journal>British Journal of Educational Technology</swrc:journal><swrc:title>How was the activity? A visualization support for a case of location-based learning design</swrc:title><swrc:year>2015</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet-si-2015 design inquiry learning teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Over the last few years the use of mobile technologies has brought the formulation of location-based learning approaches shaping new or enhanced educational activities. Involving teachers in the design of these activities is important because the designs need to be aligned with the requirements of the specific educational settings. Yet, analysing the implementation of the activities with students is also critical, not only for assessment purposes but also for enabling the identification of learning design elements that should be revised and improved. This paper studies a case that applies visualizations to support students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd self-assessment and teachers\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd inquiry of a mobile learning design. The design is a gamified location-based learning activity composed by geolocated questions and implemented with the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdQuesTInSitu: The Game\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd mobile application. The activity was designed by 7 teachers and enacted by 81 secondary education students organized in a total of 23 groups. Log files, gathered from \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdQuesTInSitu: The Game\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, provided the data for the visualizations, which represented relevant aspects of the group activity enactment (both time used to answer questions and to reach the geographical zone of the questions, scores obtained per zone, etc.). On the one hand, the visualizations were discussed with the teachers as a learning analytics tool potentially useful to consider when redesigning the activity, if needed. On the other hand, the study shows that the visualizations led students to make a better diagnose of their own activity performance.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Javier Melero"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Davinia Hern\ufffd\ufffdndez-Leo"/></rdf:_2><rdf:_3><swrc:Person swrc:name="Jing Sun"/></rdf:_3><rdf:_4><swrc:Person and"/></rdf:_1></rdf:Seq></swrc:editor></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/2d34fa44b0a9d3d17a4f67e097549fbdd/yish"><title>Informing learning 2014</swrc:date><swrc:journal>British Journal of Educational Technology</swrc:journal><swrc:title>Informing learning design with learning analytics to improve teacher inquiry</swrc:title><swrc:year>in press</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics bjet design inquiry learning teacher </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract> This paper proposes an analysis of current research in learning design (LD), a field aiming to improve the quality of educational interventions by supporting their design and fostering the sharing and reuse of innovative practices among educators. This research area, at the moment, focuses on three main strands: the representations that can be used as a common language to communicate about pedagogical plans and other half-fabricates of the design process, the methodological approaches to LD and the tools that support the LD process. For each of the three strands, the current landscape is discussed, pointing at open issues and indicating future research perspectives, with particular attention to the contribution that learning analytics can make to transform LD from a craft, based on experience, intuition and tacit knowledge, into a mature research area, grounded on data concerning the learning process and hence supporting enquiry while teachers design, run and evaluate the learning process.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Donatella Persico"/></rdf:_1><rdf:_2><swrc:Person swrc:name="Francesca Pozzi"/></rdf:_2></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item><item rdf:about="http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/282e4ebf6a22a582d54e13c7cb5685f0c/yish"><title>Computer Vision Based Attentiveness Detection Methods in E-Learning</title><link>http://www.bibsonomy.org/bibtex/282e4ebf6a22a582d54e13c7cb5685f0c/yish</link><dc:creator>yish</dc:creator><dc:date>2014-10-15T17:38:13+02:00</dc:date><dc:subject>Affective Evaluation Methodology Self-assessment analytics biometrics biosensors classroom education learning vision </dc:subject><content:encoded><span class="authorEditorList"><a href="/author/Narayanan">S. education learning vision </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>In this paper, we have reviewed the current state of the art about attentiveness detection methods used in e-learning. Classification of the prior works is done based on features measured, affective states considered, affect classification method and e-learning context. We have listed the drawbacks of webcam based elearning systems. We have also proposed a framework for elearning classroom. The different attention patterns exhibited by students under e-learning are studied. The potential applications of attentiveness detection system in e-learning are explored.</swrc:abstract><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="2660965" swrc:key="acmid"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="Amritapuri, India" swrc:key="location"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="978-1-4503-2908-8" swrc:key="isbn"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="5" swrc:key="numpages"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="51" swrc:key="articleno"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:Field swrc:value="10.1145/2660859.2660965" swrc:key="doi"/></swrc:hasExtraField><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="S. swrc:name="ACM"/></swrc:organization><swrc:pages>185--189</swrc:pages><swrc:title>MOOCs and the funnel of participation</swrc:title><swrc:year>2013</swrc:year><swrc:keywords>analytics education elearning learning m4ws moocs </swrc:keywords><swrc:abstract>Massive Online Open Courses (MOOCs) are growing substantially in numbers, and also in interest from the educational community. MOOCs offer particular challenges for what is becoming accepted as mainstream practice in learning analytics.  Partly for this reason, and partly because of the relative newness of MOOCs as a widespread phenomenon, there is not yet a substantial body of literature on the learning analytics of MOOCs. However, one clear finding is that drop-out/non-completion rates are substantially higher than in more traditional education.  This paper explores these issues, and introduces the metaphor of a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfunnel of participation\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to reconceptualise the steep drop-off in activity, and the pattern of steeply unequal participation, which appear to be characteristic of MOOCs and similar learning environments. Empirical data to support this funnel of participation are presented from three online learning sites: iSpot (observations of nature), Cloudworks (\ufffd\ufffd\ufffda place to share, find and discuss learning and teaching ideas and experiences\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd), and openED 2.0, a MOOC on business and management that ran between 2010-2012. Implications of the funnel for MOOCs, formal education, and learning analytics practice are discussed.</swrc:abstract><swrc:author><rdf:Seq><rdf:_1><swrc:Person swrc:name="Doug Clow"/></rdf:_1></rdf:Seq></swrc:author></rdf:Description></burst:publication></item></rdf:RDF>
